1906

October 18, 3912.

hr, S. C. Lak,

Angola, Indiana,

My dear Luki

Your Letter received this norning delighted ne more than I can

tell you. Primarily I was glad to hear from you, but it was also a real 
satisfaction to note by the contents and form of your letter how much you

have gained by your work of recent months.

I think that wi thout excep -
tion thi s is about the best letter I have ever received from any of the

naaerous Chinese boys who have been here, and I congratulate you on it.

It is most certainly in marked contrast to one recsived several days ago

from Fayuen Sun.

The latter, by the way, seeas to have made little if

any progress.

His case is certainly a discouraging one.

Your description of your work and the early hours at which you are

obliged to start interests and auses me greatly.

I wonder what our boya

here would say if we should ask them to report at Chapel at geven o'clock

in the morning.

Not many years ago, however, the majority of our American

educational institutions began work even earlier than this.

If I am not

mistaken, Amherst College once had its first exercise at six o'clock in the

norning.

That sort of life will

do you good, however, provided you start

to bed early enough in the avening.

He sure to get the proper amount of

sleep.

If you have that and also the necessary out-of-door exercise, the

early rising will do you more good than hari.

I cannot tell you how pleased I ar to know that you are 30 satis -
fied with your new surroundings.

That you will make the best po ssible use

of your opportunities I an absolutely confident. Your progress will always | 
interest me deaply and I shall be glad to hear from you whenever you can find

the time and inclination to write.

Every detail of your life will interest

me,

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter stating that Stearns is delighted with Luk's account of his studies and considers Luk's letter the best he has received from all the Chinese students. Stearns comments that Fayen Sun is having a difficult time, in contrast. Stearns comments on the early hour for chapel at Luk's school and commends him, while also recommending adequate sleep and exercise. Stearns is pleased that Luk is so happy with his surroundings and is confident that he will be of great service to China in the future, especially because of the current state of affairs, which he senses Luk is following closely.
